title.rendered: Olympic medals, are they really gold?

content.rendered:
It turns out that the 301 gold medals dedicated to the best athletes in the world in their respective categories actually they don’t have much gold, are made up of 93% silver, 6% copper and just 1% gold, nothing more. Ironically these medals have more silver than actual silver medals, which are made up of 92% silver and 8% copper. If an athlete were to take his 400 gram medal (the heaviest of the Olympic Games to date) to a pawn shop, he would receive no more than about $700 for it.

The awarding with medals It was the brainchild of the creator of the modern Olympic Games, the Baron de Coubertin. But at the beginning the concept was not the same as the current one. For example: at the 1896 Athens and 1900 Paris Olympics, the winner won silver and second place took bronze. Gold did not occupy the highest place on the podium until the Saint Louis Olympics in 1904.
